title: Mmmm, everything's Adlib
content:
Okay, I have done something with my high-end Windows 98 computer I never thought was possible before! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

First, I bought an older sound card that still supports OPL2/3 FM synth. Then I installed a "Yamaha OPL2/3 synth" driver that apparently comes standard with Windows 98. I set it up as the MIDI synth to use, and... Bam! All MIDIs on the PC (even those in games) are outputted through the Adlib FM synth!

I love this, everything has an Adlib sound, and if I ever get tired of it I can just switch back to MS's boring wavetable synth. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

Now to find a way to record the Adlibbed MIDIs playing... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] ____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Mmmm, everything's Adlib
content:
IIRC there is already an OPL driver for Linux, just like the OPL driver for Windows that DaVince is talking about. I think it presents a couple of MIDI devices so you can use it for playing MIDIs too.

I'm surprised you like the sound of it though DaVince, I grew up with that sound until I bought an SBLive, and I much prefer wavetable instruments for MIDI. Are you sure they removed the OPL driver in XP though?

As to how you can record it, one of the SoundBlaster 16 inputs is the FM synth, so if you have one of those cards you can use Windows Volume Control (in recording mode) to select the FM/MIDI input and then record as normal, but you do get some noise in the background.

An alternative is to build something like an [url=http://www.cc.jyu.fi/~jrop/specials/digisnap/]Adlib Digisnap[/url], but only for the truly dedicated...

Also, if you don't want to add a new sound card to your PC, you might consider downloading some MIDI playing software for DOS (I use Creative Labs' original SoundBlaster playback software - I can post it here if anyone is interested.) This will let you play back MIDIs through DOSBox using the emulated FM synth, which you can then record to .wav or capture to .dro and play back in Winamp/XMMS with AdPlug. It also uses slightly different OPL instruments to the Windows driver, so the MIDIs sound slightly different.

title: Re: Mmmm, everything's Adlib
content:
I liked that SNES SoundFont, but I don't think there's too much call for using the latest audio technology to reproduce the oldest.

And I really must be not paying enough attention - I don't think I've ever noticed a difference between DOSBox and a real OPL (well not a big difference anyway.)

If you really want to record the OPL stuff on the cheap you can do it the 'crapola' way, which is to get one of those headphone loopback cables (they have a headphone plug on both ends) and plug the OPL card's line out into a halfway decent card's line in (most discount stores stock cables like this, or if they don't, they stock enough other cables and adapters that you can construct your own.) Then just record from one card while you play back on the other. It's probably easier if you use two different PCs, but if you set up the devices properly in Windows it's simple enough using just the one PC (but you'll probably need two sound cards, because most cards with OPL chips were of the era before you could record and play back at the same time...)

...or you could just get an ISA SoundBlaster 16 or a PCI SB Vibra off eBay which *can* record off its internal OPL3 input.
